html.p: What: Filters data based on a regular expression. Can include or exclude lines.

ol.li: Don't confuse with the command rex!
Be aware that pipes | and backslashes \ need special attention.

html.p: Why: More complex filtering/searching is possible through it.

So What: I honestly have never used it in a production environment. I prefer using rex to create a new field out of the things I want/don't want and then use a standard | search ... to do this instead. I know, I'm crazy.

panel.html:
The data we are using for this command: | inputlookup mydata.csv | rename "Cars Sold This Hour" AS carsSoldPerHour | eval carsSoldPerHour = 6 * carsSoldPerHour
Note that we use our base lookup, but a) I rename that terribly long fieldname with spaces (now that we know how to do that), and b) I also multiply the number of cars per hour by 6 to give us some neat things to work with.
Note the x6 of the cars sold per hour, and it being renamed.
panel.title: Original (slightly modified) data

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | rename "Cars Sold This Hour" AS carsSoldPerHour | eval carsSoldPerHour = 6 * carsSoldPerHour

panel.html: Filtered with | regex carsSoldPerHour="\d{2,}" which tells it to include only rows where carsSoldPerHour is two or more digits.
panel.title: Regex is fun!

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | rename "Cars Sold This Hour" AS carsSoldPerHour | eval carsSoldPerHour = 6 * carsSoldPerHour | regex carsSoldPerHour="\d{2,}"
